reviewText: Ihave always loved the story of beowulf.  I was excited to see the movie when it came out, but by the end I was more interested in finding how they ever made the film.  The documentary is wonderful.  It lays out the reality of making movies and also about following your vision against great odds.  The landscape, business, and unexpected pitfalls do not seem to sway people who are passionate about their art. I am so happy this film was made.
summary: Exciting and helpful to understanding film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I can't believe what I'm seeing...a solid hour interview with Gerry Butler AFTER a grueling workday on the set.  I'm amazed at his patience under the visible stress of an aching head and body after braving the Icelandic weather to shoot this revealing documentation.  How much more can he do to show his appreciation for the support of his fans worldwide?  His behavior speaks volumes about the depth of his character and his commitment to excellence and dedication as an actor.  His star is definitely rising and he is indeed 'paying his dues'...he is not afraid to shoulder the tough roles, transforming himself into a character in ways that startle directors and producers alike.  When he signs on to play a role they can be assured of this:  they will get much, much more than their money's worth from the likes of this humble, towering Scotsman who has his feet planted solidly on the ground and who has restored the grandeur of moviemaking.  Don't look for his handsome face in the gossip rags as he's rarely caught up in their sordid stories...he's too mature to get swept up in their tasteless diatribes...he's too busy concentrating on his career to cater to the crowded flashbulbs.  The law profession lost an excellent attorney when he set his sights on becoming an actor; can't you just see him in the courtroom making his case summarization!  He's stunning in a suit and tie but even better in his preferred 'dressed-down' look of an old tee shirt, old jeans and an old leather jacket - like in THE JURY film...go getum, Gerry.  I may be old enough to be his mother, but I can hardly breathe when he's on camera...go figure.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just bought this DVD documentary  and thought it was excellent.  How this film Beowulf and Grendel ever got made, I do not know!  Seems like the UK money people should take a lot of responsibility for the problems.  Even during the Gerry Butler interview the lights went out, and they had to light his trailer with truck headlights!The interview with Gerry really makes you appreciate his dedication to his art, regardless of the quality of the film.  He is very articulate and well informed,and have not seen any of the other major stars do much like this.  He is also, to my surprise, a co-producer on the documentary.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I don't know that I would have gone out of my way to watch this documentary about making a movie in Iceland. It seems like an experience for those not propone to deadlines.  All in all, this movie proved to be informative and entertaining.  We're planning a trip to Iceland as an adventure.  This movie whet my appetite for both Iceland and Beowulf and Grendel.

reviewText: I purchased because Gerard Butler was in it.  It turned out to be a fascinating DVD about the making of Beowulf & Grendel in an unbelievable environment.  I continued to watch because it gave a clear picture of how the movie making business really operates.  i wish there were more DVDs of this genre.  It makes you  appreciate what the cast & crew go thru to bring a movie to the theaterWould recommend if this subject matter is of interest to you.  .

reviewText: Very verbose and drawn out.  Yes it is obvious they picked a hostile environment to film in.  I wonder if Jon Gustafsson ever watched the extras on A&E's Shackelton, with Kenneth Branagh.  Talk about hostile environments.  I guess the difference was that they had their funding in place before they started shooting.  That should not be "the big scary" on a movie set.

reviewText: This is a wonderful dvd about the behind the scenes of the movie Beowulf and Grendel. It definately is worth buying especially if you are a Gerard Butler fan. The main 'feature' is about how they could afford to make the movie, and how they actually made the movie in the weather of Iceland. It's really great, and exciting. There's that, and then there's all these outtakes and deleted scenes along with interviews of the cast members. Gerard Butler's interview is over an hour long! If you are a fan of Gerry's, I think you will really enjoy this dvd! I know I do.

reviewText: It was quite interesting to see the optimism of the film crew as they faced various conflicts within the making of this movie. Gives good insight into the film industry.

reviewText: This is an amazing video and one you will enjoy (in the warmth of your home,inside)  I enjoyed it from start to finish and recommend it to anyone that loves adventure and beautiful human spirit. I bought it because Gerard was featured in it and love it because it is truly a wonderful story of a determined group of people who set out to show what they faced making a movie (Beowulf & Grendel on location , In Iceland, instead of a movie set.)Freezing cold temperatures, gale force winds, pouring rain, driving snow, oozing mud, thick fog would seem to be an indomitable force to contend with but their perseverence and tenacity to go on proved an awarding experience to be able to give the viewing public a masterpiece of such awe inspiring footage that one has to see it to believe it.

reviewText: This was a wonderful example of what goes wrong and what goes right in filmmaking.  I am amazed how much these people went through in creating "Boewulf and Grendel," and I am certainly glad they did.  Both "The Wrath of God" and "Boewulf and Grendel" are excellent.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Why all the 4 & 5 star reviews?  This is a movie about making a movie.  The Icelandic landscape is compelling ... but this movie is extremely boring otherwise.  Yes, they chose a bad location to make a movie.  Harsh weather conditions, problems with the financial backers, and they ran behind schedule and over budget.  So what?  Who cares?  I watched only for the beauty of the landscape but I might have watched a nature show filmed in Iceland and learned more about the ecology of the place.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Have seen Beowulf and Grendel and it was OK but I really enjoyed The Wrath of God.  To see the trials they ALL went through i.e. hurricane, storms, wind and fire was incredible.  I couldn't believe that cast and crew stuck it out till the finish! It is well worth viewing.  I'm so glad I purchased it. You will need to use English subtitles for some of the screens but they speak English approx. 60% of the time.  Gerry Butler is all English (as well as others)

reviewText: I have to admit, I gave up on this one and, if it got exciting later on, I missed it.  As far as I got, it all seemed about bad weather, late set production, and lack of funding.  Seems to me, they could have called it "Wrath of Poor Planning."  Considering the quality of Beowulf and Grendl, this came as quite a surprise.

reviewText: Here you have a display of determination, hope, and back-breaking work ethic.  A film that is plagued with natural and financial disasters.  A crew and cast hell-bent on making a story hit the big screen.  Without pay.  Without comfort.  Without food and gas at some points.  Without support from those promising financial backing overseas.  Under questionably safe conditions.  Braving frighteningly tentative weather that thrashes them one hour and warms them with the sun the next.  Stranded in Iceland, bearing freak occurrences that make you wonder if the gods and trolls and alfar were actually meddling with these poor artists.  Or should I say testing their mettle?The movie may not be the best adaptation of Beowulf.  In fact, it is a disappointment in many respects.  Still, it is a miracle that this movie was even made!  I think there is incredible value in the tale of this movie's production--more so than in the actual movie itself.  There is a lesson that perhaps Odin wanted communicated: suffer valiantly, strive with honor and heart, let the weak give up, let the fools scramble away, and produce your work at all costs with all the talent that you can, under all conditions--just to see it done.  And done well.These actors and crew members deserve our respect.  In an age where Hollywood film industry people are so full of themselves, so vapid, so weak-kneed and uncreative, we can compare them to Gustafsson and his miracle workers.  We can differentiate true artists from true wastes.  True warriors from true cowards.  Vikings from children.I want to BUY the actual movie now just to honor the inspiring efforts of these people.Give this a watch ESPECIALLY if you are interested in film-making, filming on location, life behind the scenes with actors, and so on.  Good stuff.
Title: N/A
